author: By Ronen Bergman and Oscar Lopez
title: Former Official Wanted by Mexico Takes Refuge in Israel
description: Israel has refused to extradite Tomás Zerón, accused of torture and evidence tampering, because of Mexico’s criticism of the country, an Israeli official said.
content: TEL AVIV — A former top Mexican official accused of compromising the investigation of a notorious mass abduction has taken refuge in Israel while the extradition case against him is mired in a diplomatic tussle over Israel’s treatment of Palestinians, Israeli and Mexican officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Eric Schmitt and Megan Specia
title: Haiti Police Hold President’s Palace Security Chief
description: Dimitri Hérard was placed in police custody as accusations focused on any possible insider connection to President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The head of palace security for President Jovenel Moïse, who was assassinated last week at his home, was taken into police custody on Thursday, deepening investigators’ focus into the possibility that Haitian insiders had eased the killers’ path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Canada Nixes Plan to Bring Extra Michigan Vaccines to Border Tunnel
description: Since the Canadian government won’t allow surplus U.S. vaccines into the country, one mayor proposed an ambitious plan to vaccinate residents inside a tunnel under the Detroit River.
content: The Canadian government has blocked an Ontario mayor’s plan to vaccinate residents in a tunnel on the U.S. border, using some of Michigan’s surplus, soon-to-expire Covid-19 vaccine doses, the mayor said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kisselgoff
title: Oleg Briansky, Star Dancer Turned Star Teacher, Is Dead at 91
description: When his career was ended by a bad knee, he and his wife and fellow dancer opened what became one of the most prestigious ballet academies in America.
content: Oleg Briansky, who distinguished himself first as an international ballet star and then as an influential ballet teacher, died on July 7 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Growth Slows as Pandemic Fears Persist
description: Growth in the world’s second-largest economy lost steam as more expensive raw materials weighed on factories, though retail sales showed signs of stabilizing.
content: BEIJING — After a year of leading the global economy out of the pandemic slump, China’s growth is now starting to level off, as the world tries to assess whether the country’s recovery will continue or peter out.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Delta Variant Widens Gulf Between ‘2 Americas’
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 15, 2021.
content: “Delta is creating a huge amount of noise, but I don’t think that it’s right to be ringing a huge alarm bell.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Art and politics snuggle comfortably in this week’s recommended titles — explicitly so in some cases (a novel about Benjamin Netanyahu’s father, activist poetry from June Jordan and Muriel Rukeyser), and in other cases through simple proximity (a biography of Jimmy Carter just down the shelf from Brandon Taylor’s story collection, a book about democracy alongside novels set in Barcelona and rural France). There’s also a meditation on motherhood by Michelle Orange, and Jonathan Balcombe’s multifaceted look at the life of flies. Yes, flies. They may not know much about art, but Balcombe has me halfway convinced they’d be good at politics anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Maurizio Cattelan’s New Work Pays Visceral Tribute to the Pain of 9/11
description: A sculpture at an exhibition in Milan provides a graphic reminder of the terror attacks. The Guggenheim Museum’s former chief curator said it may best be appreciated, for now, outside New York.
content: The Italian artist Maurizio Cattelan has seldom shied from creating works that raise eyebrows. He is, after all, the person responsible for that $120,000 banana, and the popular, highly symbolic gold toilet that went missing in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Mama Weed’ Review: Huppert Slings Hash
description: Not even the greatest living French actress can redeem this witless crime caper.
content: The police captain, on a date with a translator in his department, tries to compliment her with an observation about her “paradoxical” nature. She seems so small and fragile, and yet she possesses such extraordinary self-confidence!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: F.A.A. tells airlines to inspect Boeing 737 switches that could pose a safety risk.
description: Airlines have not reported any failures that led to a dangerous drop in oxygen levels during flight.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration on Thursday instructed airlines to inspect a pair of cabin air pressure switches on all Boeing 737 planes, citing safety concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Leigh
title: The Cure for Overtourism? Try Viljandi.
description: Doubly off the beaten track, the Estonian town is full of life and culture, especially music. And if travel is going to change its ways, it’s a good place to start.
content: Traveling to the interior of a small country that doesn’t see huge numbers of tourists you can usually count on certain things: peace and quiet, pastoral landscapes and maybe a few inquisitive looks. Occasionally, though, you come across a small town that’s especially full of life — without the crowds and traffic of a metropolis. There’s good food and culture and interesting people to meet, and it feels as if you have all of it to yourself. These are the little communities for which it’s worth going out of your way. Viljandi, a small town in the south of Estonia not far from the Latvian border, is such a place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Democrats Push a Budget to Fulfill Biden’s Aggressive Economic Ambitions
description: The $3.5 trillion blueprint under consideration in the Senate would deliver, at least temporarily, on the economic promise of a unified Washington run by Democrats.
content: WASHINGTON — The $3.5 trillion budget blueprint that Democrats unveiled in the Senate this week promises to reshape the government’s role in the economy, in ways President Biden and his party have called essential to rebuilding the American middle class, lifting people out of poverty and tackling the threat of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsey Underwood
title: Britney Spears Fans Wore Their Support on Their Sleeves
description: A crowd of supporters gathered outside a Los Angeles courthouse on Wednesday to protest the pop star’s conservatorship.
content: Outside a Los Angeles courthouse on Wednesday, throngs of Britney Spears fans — and nearly an equal number of reporters and photographers — gathered under the afternoon sun as a judge evaluated Ms. Spears’s legal representation and conservatorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Zeidner
title: The Sneaky Subversiveness of Laurie Colwin
description: The beloved food and fiction writer, who died too young in 1992, wrote about happiness but with more irony and ambiguity than you might think. All 10 of Colwin’s books are being rereleased this year, which makes now the perfect time to revisit them.
content: Laurie Colwin may be the only fiction writer in history who is known more for her recipes than her novels. Colwin, who died in 1992 at age 48 of an aortic aneurysm, was a contributor to Gourmet magazine and had a cultlike following for her food writing. Pre-Instagram, when broccoli rabe was still an exotic vegetable and you could exult about discovering scallion pancakes in Chinatown (“I had not known that such things existed”), Colwin had only her words to describe memorable meals with family and friends. “I am not a fancy cook or an ambitious one,” she admitted in “Home Cooking,” and she often celebrated the plain thing done perfectly, like her legendary roasted chicken. The same kind of unfussy delight could describe her fictional voice, in which she presents marriages that shimmer with an ineffable rightness, and extols family as “a haven in a heartless world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Big Spending Got Its Groove Back
description: There has been a huge change in what's considered politically feasible.
content: The way it was: Some years ago I attended a meeting in which President Barack Obama asked a group of economists for unconventional policy ideas. I distinctly remember him saying: “Don’t tell me that I should spend a trillion dollars on infrastructure. I know that, but I can’t do it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Jones
title: ‘Modern Love’ Season 2: Watch the Trailer
description: Don’t worry — Modern Love is still a column and a podcast. But, as you may recall, it’s also a series on Prime Video. Beginning Aug. 13, you can watch eight new episodes.
content: Nearly two years ago, “Modern Love” premiered worldwide as an eight-episode streaming series on Prime Video. Inspired by essays from the Modern Love column, the episodes explored love in New York City in many forms, including dating with bipolar disorder and a gay couple adopting a baby girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: The Movies Are Back. But What Are Movies Now?
description: Cinephiles and streaming fans can both claim victory. But as we better understand the new screen culture taking shape, it looks like we may all lose in the long run.
content: Have you seen “F9”? How about “A Quiet Place Part II”? “Black Widow”? “Zola”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Push to ‘Free Britney’ Gains Steam on Capitol Hill
description: As lawmakers share social media posts and messages of solidarity, activists hope the increased attention on Britney Spears’s conservatorship case will prompt legislative change.
content: In the weeks since Britney Spears publicly denounced the long-running legal arrangement that has controlled her life, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have jumped in to declare their support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Mujib Mashal
title: Millions of children missed out on basic vaccinations during the pandemic.
description: About 23 million young people were not inoculated against diseases like measles and polio last year. The number was the highest since 2009, the W.H.O. and UNICEF said.
content: About 23 million children missed out on basic childhood vaccines last year, the World Health Organization and UNICEF said on Thursday, warning about a devastating consequence of the Covid-19 pandemic for routine health services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: It’s Too Early to Celebrate the Child Tax Credit
description: The victory that Democrats celebrated on Thursday hasn’t  been won. The tax credit remains temporary, and coverage is incomplete.
content: The United States provides big tax incentives to encourage people to work, to buy a home, to save for retirement. But the government provides less money than almost every other developed nation to help people raise children. Last year, the tax credit for buying an electric car was almost four times as large as the tax credit for having a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Schiffman
title: Nature as a Salve for Children With Autism
description: The intense focus that some kids bring to video games can carry over to being captivated by minute details in the natural world: the sound of a single insect or the texture of a blade of grass.
content: Erin Laraway and four of her students were pulling radishes from raised growing beds in a vest-pocket garden tucked into the side of the Brooklyn Occupational Training Center, a public high school for adolescents with special needs in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn one recent Friday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Farida Khelfa Wants to Challenge the Image of Middle Eastern Women
description: One of fashion’s first top Arab models has a new documentary about the creative class in Dubai, Saudi Arabia and Qatar.
content: It came as no surprise to see Farida Khelfa sitting in the front row at last week’s fashion shows in Paris, with her signature chopped haircut and wide smile. Two of the biggest shows were essentially tributes to Azzedine Alaïa and Jean Paul Gaultier, designers who took inspiration from and helped elevate Ms. Khelfa to supermodel status in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Laura Mvula Set Her Sound Free. It Ended Up in the ’80s.
description: After five years between albums, the award-winning English songwriter changed everything, trading orchestras for synthesizers and cranking up the beat.
content: The English songwriter Laura Mvula changed nearly everything as she made her third album. She changed her sound, her songwriting method, her collaborators and (involuntarily) her label. After two award-winning, brilliantly idiosyncratic albums of time-warped orchestral pop, Mvula’s latest, “Pink Noise,” swerves in an entirely different direction: toward the brash, glossy, synthesizer-driven R&B-pop of the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Breyer, under pressure to retire from the Supreme Court, says he has not decided on his future.
description: Justice Breyer says he is enjoying a new position of influence on the court as the most senior of its liberal faction.
content: Justice Stephen G. Breyer, 82, says he has no plans to retire despite calls from progressives demanding the 27-year Supreme Court veteran step down voluntarily to ensure that Senate Democrats have the opportunity to confirm a liberal successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Slone
title: Granny Panties of Yore Reinvented for a New Customer
description: ARQ undies have built a cult following based on their coverage, comfort and counterintuitive sex appeal.
content: In September 2019, Lydia Okello, a content creator who works primarily with slow fashion brands, received an email from a small underwear company offering to send a package of its products, with no pressure to post about them. Mx. Okello agreed, and within two weeks, a recyclable package containing a soft lilac bralette and a matching pair of vertiginously high-waisted panties arrived at their doorstep in Vancouver, British Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: They Risked Their Lives During Covid. They Still Don’t Earn Minimum Wage.
description: Surveys of food deliverers and others who work for app-based services illustrate the hazards they have faced during the pandemic.
content: They zipped around New York City on bikes, bringing restaurant meals to customers too fearful to venture out. Others drove for Uber and Lyft, ferrying different passengers, never knowing if they might be risking their health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: After Fires, Chevrolet Bolt Owners Are Warned: Don’t Park Indoors
description: Even electric vehicles serviced in response to a recall last year may still be at risk, the vehicle’s manufacturer and federal safety officials said.
content: Two Chevrolet Bolt EVs recently caught fire after they were repaired as part of a recall last year that affected nearly 51,000 vehicles in the United States, federal safety officials announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: White flags along the National Mall will mark more than 600,000 U.S. Covid deaths.
description: For two weeks starting on Sept. 17, the flags will blanket 20 acres of federal parkland near the Washington Monument.
content: Hundreds of thousands of white flags will be planted along the National Mall in Washington in September to memorialize the more than 600,000 people who have died from Covid-19 in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Inflation? Not in Japan. And That Could Hold a Warning for the U.S.
description: If the United States’ bout of rising prices soon eases, its economy could fall back into the cycle of weak inflation that preceded the pandemic — a situation much like Japan’s.
content: TOKYO — In the United States, everyone is talking about inflation. The country’s reopening from the coronavirus pandemic has unleashed pent-up demand for everything from raw materials like lumber to secondhand goods like used cars, pushing up prices at the fastest clip in over a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: De Blasio and Cuomo Feuded. How Will Adams Fare?
description: Eric Adams, the likely next mayor,   made a public appearance with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and   emphasized areas of common ground.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The Delta surge.
content: Coronavirus cases are once again rising in the U.S., fueled by the Delta variant and the sagging vaccination campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Europe’s plan for a carbon-neutral future.
content: Europe plans to move away from fossil fuels, with an ambitious fleet of new policies that would include eliminating sales of new gas- and diesel-powered cars, raising the price of using fossil fuels and imposing tariffs on countries with looser climate rules — potentially setting off trade disputes with the U.S. and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger and Monika Pronczuk
title: Poland Escalates Fight With Europe Over the Rule of Law
description: Hungary and Poland are fighting with Brussels over values and rule of law. So, after a fashion, is Germany.
content: BRUSSELS — Poland has escalated a six-year struggle with the European Union over the rule of law after the country’s constitutional court ruled it did not have to comply with an order from the bloc’s supreme court over its oversight of judges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Why Married Men Might Be an Overlooked but Crucial Voting Bloc
description: The gender gap is well known in politics. The marriage gap is more obscure — but could inform how campaigns think about key groups of voters in the next elections.
content: The gender gap is one of the best-known dynamics in American politics. Put simply: Women lean liberal, men lean conservative. (As a character in “The West Wing” put it: “If women were the only voters, the Democrats would win in a landslide every time. If men were the only voters, the G.O.P. would be the left-wing party.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden makes a new push in fight against ransomware, including a $10 million reward.
description: The Biden administration is making a new push to disrupt ransomware attacks on American companies, offering a $10 million reward for information that leads to the arrest of the gangs behind the extortion schemes and attempting to make it easier to trace and block cryptocurrency payments, administration officials said Thursday.
content: The Biden administration is making a new push to disrupt ransomware attacks on American companies, offering a $10 million reward for information that leads to the arrest of the gangs behind the extortion schemes and attempting to make it easier to trace and block cryptocurrency payments, administration officials said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our critic recommends an emotional sports documentary, a ghost show and a terrific coming-of-age comedy.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ex-Military Commander in Canada Is Charged With Obstruction of Justice
description: The criminal charges against the former chief of the defense staff came out of an investigation into sexual misconduct.
content: OTTAWA — Canada’s former top military officer, under investigation for sexual misconduct, was charged with obstruction of justice on Thursday, the latest in a series of events that have highlighted widespread harassment and conflicts of interest in the country’s military, much of it involving the force’s elite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: What Happens When a Private Club Goes Public?
description: Soho House will begin trading. All eyes are on whether stock market investors will sign up.
content: The parent company of Soho House, the chain of upscale members’ clubs for celebrities and well-heeled young professionals, is to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange today. But after pricing its I.P.O. at the low end of expectations, the question it faces is whether it can deliver on ambitious growth targets while keeping its cool, DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes for The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Hopeful News on Delta
description: The Delta variant is more contagious. It does not appear to be more severe.
content: There are two basic questions to ask about any variant of the Covid-19 virus: Is it more contagious than earlier versions of the virus? And is it more severe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Los Angeles County will require masks to be worn indoors as Delta variant spreads.
description: Public health officials in the county had already been urging residents to wear masks indoors. The mandate will begin Saturday night, just before midnight.
content: Los Angeles County announced Thursday that it will require masks to be worn inside regardless of vaccination status, as the highly contagious Delta variant spreads throughout California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: At a Cultural Hub in Bethlehem, Art Thrives in the Fray
description: At Dar Jacir, an art center in a “difficult location,” people are searching for ways to make art under siege.
content: One of Dima Srouji’s most vivid childhood memories of her hometown, Bethlehem, occurred in front of the house known as Dar Jacir. It was the year 2000, and she and her mother were driving past the historic but crumbling 19th-century villa along the main road connecting Jerusalem and Hebron when they were stopped by a group of young Palestinian men who urged them to roll up their windows and find another route to their destination. The second intifada had begun and the air was heavy with tear gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: A human case of bird flu is reported in China.
description: State news media said that a 55-year-old man had been hospitalized with the H5N6 virus but that the risk of large-scale transmission was low.
content: A man has been hospitalized in southwestern China after contracting the H5N6 strain of avian flu, Chinese state news media reported on Thursday, a reminder that the world is full of flu viruses even during a coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Christian Boltanski, Whose Art Installations Dazzled, Dies at 76
description: In often sprawling works that used old photos, discarded clothes and other found objects, he pondered loss, chance and memory.
content: Christian Boltanski, an internationally acclaimed artist whose striking installations dealt with themes of memory and forgotten lives, chance and fate, death and the passage of time, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 76 and lived just outside the city, in Malakoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: ‘Faster, Harder, Louder’: Rolling Stone Hires Daily Beast Editor
description: Noah Shachtman, an experienced online journalist with a newsy sensibility, will lead the pop music bible founded in 1967.
content: Rolling Stone has chosen Noah Shachtman, the top editor of the news site The Daily Beast, as its next editor in chief, the magazine announced on Thursday, calling on him to continue the transformation of the 54-year-old pop music bible into a digital-first publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Soho House Enters Club of Its Own: The Stock Market
description: The chain of exclusive clubs has lost money for its entire existence, but it pitched investors on plans for rapid growth and a pandemic-proof business.
content: LONDON — Since its inception, the Soho House chain of members clubs has been associated with exclusive hangouts for the jet set, where celebrities and deep-pocketed professionals shell out thousands of dollars each year to gather in sleekly designed urban redoubts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Andrea Arnold Has Directed A-Listers. Her Latest Star? This Cow
description: Arnold’s new documentary, “Cow,” is one of the most moving films at Cannes. “A few times, I’ve just burst into tears about it,” she says.
content: CANNES, France — Andrea Arnold waved her hands in front of her face, trying to keep her composure. “I’m a bit pathetic today, sorry,” the British director said, tearing up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Jeff Bezos Picks 18-Year-Old Dutch Student for Blue Origin Rocket Launch
description: Oliver Daemen will fly to the edge of space after another passenger who paid $28 million for the seat had a scheduling conflict.
content: Someone paid $28 million to not go to space with Jeff Bezos next week. Instead, an 18-year-old from the Netherlands will join the flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘Toofaan’ Review: Raising a Storm
description: The Bollywood director Rakeysh Omprakash Mehra attempts — with some success — to deepen the standard-issue sports drama with sociopolitical strife ripped from Indian headlines.
content: When Aziz Ali (Farhan Akhtar), the starry-eyed gangster at the heart of “Toofaan,” first comes across videos of Muhammad Ali, he’s hooked. Though it goes unsaid, the appeal clearly isn’t just the boxer’s athletic artistry — it’s also his chosen name. To our hero, Ali is one of his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Margolick
title: Song of the Subway: Walt Whitman on the Downtown Express
description: As New York returns, and the trains are running 24 hours a day again, let us pause to marvel at the convulsive wonder underneath our very feet.
content: I wasn’t thinking about Walt Whitman when I hopped on the subway at 72nd and Broadway. My time was short, and I wanted only to get down to Chambers Street as quickly as possible, before the courthouses on Foley Square closed. But what happened on the first leg of my trip prompted my own poor imitation of a Whitman poem. Call it “Song of the Subway.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Curious Case of the Quirky Mortgage Ads Boosting Biden Online
description: A mortgage-related firm called Lower My Bills has spent more than $10 million on Facebook ads in recent months, invoking President Biden’s name in ostentatious pitches.
content: The single biggest advertiser in Facebook’s political advertising database in recent months is not President Biden, the Democratic or Republican parties or even any of the hundreds of candidates angling for advantage in the 2022 midterms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tess Gerritsen Still Prefers to Read Books the Old-Fashioned Way, on Paper
description: “I’m one of those terrible book owners who bends down the corners of pages to mark my place.”
content: “I’m one of those terrible book owners who bends down the corners of pages to mark my place,” says the novelist, whose new thriller with Gary Braver is “Choose Me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Homeopathic Doctor Is Charged With Selling Fake Covid-19 Vaccine Cards
description: Juli Mazi of Napa, Calif., also sold “immunization pellets” to patients, federal prosecutors said.
content: A homeopathic doctor in California is the first person to face federal charges for selling fake Covid-19 vaccination cards, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Broadway Is Back! A Guide to Shows, Tickets and Covid Protocols.
description: We break down everything you need to navigate Broadway as it reopens.
content: Broadway got through all of last year, and it’s here. It’s still here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: A British Open Comeback: A Two-Year Wait Ends at Royal St. George’s
description: The Open, the only men’s major tournament to shut down last year because of the pandemic, returns with spectators and some strict limitations.
content: SANDWICH, England — Just ahead of the British Open at Royal St. George’s Golf Club, Edward Kitson walked briskly through the dunes on Wednesday night, making his way to the clubhouse and thinking back to last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: No Kid Should Be Heckled by Their Parents. Right?
description: A reader asks whether it would have been right to intervene when she saw two adults putting undue pressure on their child.
content: I was at Lake Huron recently, and I saw two parents bullying their young son who was about 7 years old. He was refusing to jump off a giant boulder into the rocky water 15 feet below. His parents were heckling him about it, saying things like, “Thanks for not trusting me, son!” The boy looked terrified. Admittedly, there were younger kids who were jumping off the rocks. But it made me sick to my stomach to do nothing other than glare at those awful parents. Should I have said something?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: In a First, an M.L.B. Game Will be Called Entirely by Women
description: “It can’t help but feel different,” said Alanna Rizzo, who will be part of the crew for an Orioles-Rays game alongside Melanie Newman, Sarah Langs, Heidi Watney and Lauren Gardner.
content: Next week, for the first time on a broadcast, fans of Major League Baseball can watch a game in which they might not hear a man’s voice. Five women will serve as the on-air crew for the Baltimore Orioles game against the Tampa Bay Rays from St. Petersburg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Shashank Bengali and Anna Schaverien
title: After marches in Europe against vaccination rules, the W.H.O. warns the pandemic is ‘nowhere near finished.’
description: Thousands of protesters in France and Greece marched on Wednesday against the inoculation campaigns in both countries after the authorities announced new coronavirus vaccination requirements this week.
content: Thousands of protesters in France and Greece marched on Wednesday against the inoculation campaigns in both countries after the authorities announced new coronavirus vaccination requirements this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘No Ordinary Man’ Review: The Life and Death of Billy Tipton
description: This documentary sheds light on a prominent jazz musician whose death became a spectacle when it was discovered he was transgender.
content: The documentary “No Ordinary Man” examines the life and death of Billy Tipton, a jazz musician who came into prominence in the 1930s, and whose career lasted for over 40 years. Billy was described by his friends as a consummate gentleman, and he cherished his family, with three children he adopted with his partner, Kitty. Billy lived his life quietly, but his death in 1989 became a nationwide spectacle after it became clear during funeral preparations that he was transgender. Members of his family made appearances on talk shows, including “The Oprah Winfrey Show,” where they attested they did not know Billy was transgender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: In ‘Bach & Sons,’ a Composer Stares Down Death
description: The new play at the Bridge Theater in London and two other productions on the city’s stages examine characters facing the end.
content: LONDON — Few actors could stare down mortality better than Simon Russell Beale in “Bach & Sons,” a problematic new play at the Bridge Theater that benefits from a piercing central performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Boys in Red Hats’ Review: Cool Story, Bro
description: This documentary explores the incident on Jan. 18, 2019, when a high school student grinned and stared at a Native American demonstrator at a raucous Lincoln Memorial gathering.
content: Jonathan Schroder’s “The Boys in Red Hats” is a maddening instance of a movie at war with itself. That’s appropriate enough since its subject is the encounter on Jan. 18, 2019, between white high school students and a Native American demonstrator at the Lincoln Memorial. The incident became a viral flash point over one teenager’s grinning in the face of the Native American elder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Basketball Is Nothing Without Net
description: “It is just not good,” Anibal Amador says of bare rims at New York City’s playgrounds. As a result, the self-described “Net Changer” buys and hangs nets at his local courts.
content: One of the most gratifying sounds in sports is the whoosh of a basketball snapping the netting on a perfect swish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Art Meets Its Soundtrack Deep in ‘The Dirty South’
description: A big, juicy exhibition at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts turns an embracing eye on Black artists in the American South.
content: RICHMOND, Va. — Some of the country’s most candidly truth-telling museums dedicated to the civil rights movement, and by extension to Black history, are in cities south of the Mason-Dixon line: Jackson, Memphis and Montgomery among them. Which suggests that old, sweeping views of the South as a bastion of stuck-in-past political denial are, and have always been, wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cubans Take to the Streets
description: What prompted the largest protests in Cuba in 30 years?
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: A Block to Remember Evens the Series for the Bucks
description: Deandre Ayton seemed to be wide open next to the basket. Giannis Antetokounmpo had other ideas.
content: MILWAUKEE — When the lob was in the air, it looked to be a sure dunk. The Phoenix Suns were down 2 with 1:17 left in the fourth quarter of Wednesday night’s Game 4, and a basket would tie the game and give the Suns a puncher’s chance to push the Milwaukee Bucks to the brink of elimination in the N.B.A. finals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain’ Review: Salt, Sugar and No Fat
description: Morgan Neville’s sharp and vividly compelling documentary tries to pin down a brilliant, troubled man.
content: There’s scarcely a dry eye in the frame at the conclusion of Morgan Neville’s vivid, jam-packed documentary, “Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain,” but this isn’t a hagiography. Bourdain, who died almost exactly three years ago at the age of 61, was many things — chef, sensualist, addict, world traveler — any one of which could have served as the movie’s lodestar. Yet it was as a writer that he found renown, and it is around his words that “Roadrunner” constructs its ominous, uneasy shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Treatment for gun injuries costs more than $1 billion a year, federal watchdog says.
description: Medicaid and other public programs cover more than 60 percent of those emergency bills, but the costs of long term health care are still unknown.
content: In a groundbreaking report released on Wednesday, a federal watchdog estimated that the cost of medical treatment for survivors of gun injuries in the United States amounts to at least $1 billion each year, but is likely much higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner
title: Co-Working Spaces Are Back. And There Are Many, Many Options.
description: As the office world adjusts to a new normal and workers grow tired of their homes, WeWork and its competitors reap the benefits.
content: Though Kia Roberts, who runs her own misconduct investigation firm, originally felt hesitant about joining The Wing, the feminist-aligned co-working space and social club, she fell in love with it after a visit to its Dumbo location in early 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Raffaella Carrà, Saucy Superstar of Italian TV, Dies at 78
description: Known for her energetic dancing and singing as well as for conducting serious interviews, she was beloved by Italians of all generations.
content: Raffaella Carrà, one of Italy’s best-known television personalities, who shimmied, danced and sang across prime time as a racy presence during a staid era but also hosted a serious talk show, died on July 5 in Rome. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Ponders Inflation ‘Night and Day,’ Fed Chair Tells Lawmakers
description: Jerome H. Powell told senators that price gains should fade, but he made it clear that the Fed is watching them carefully.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, acknowledged to senators on Thursday that inflation had risen to uncomfortably high levels and said he and his colleagues were watching price gains carefully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Biden’s nominees to lead ICE and the Border Patrol are a sharp departure from the Trump era.
description: If they are confirmed, Ed Gonzalez and Chris Magnus would be responsible for delivering on President Biden’s promise to return compassion to the immigration system.
content: WASHINGTON — Ed Gonzalez, the sheriff of Harris County, Texas, made ending a partnership with Immigration and Customs Enforcement one of his first decisions on the job because, he said, the program encouraged “illegal racial profiling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Lebanon’s Designated Prime Minister Quits Amid Swirling Crises
description: After nine months of political wrangling, Saad Hariri gave up on trying to form a government, opening a new political void.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Former Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon said on Thursday that he had given up on trying to form a new government, opening a new political void as the country sinks further into an acute political and economic crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Die in a Gunfight’ Review: Another Tale of Star-Crossed Lovers
description: This hyper-stylized, neon-soaked take on “Romeo and Juliet” tries hard to be slick; too bad it’s so amateurish.
content: Combine edgy action movie clichés with a hackneyed “Romeo and Juliet”-inspired screenplay and you get “Die in a Gunfight,” a neon-saturated shoot-’em-up that follows a pair of brooding lovers as they fend off their mobster-ish parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: What Happened to Airbnb During the Pandemic?
description: Listings on the rental site dropped precipitously, but people who rented stayed longer.
content: When Covid-19 restrictions took travelers off the road, it was no surprise that the short-term rental industry suffered. A new study of 20 major Airbnb markets conducted by LendingTree showed that in 19 the number of short-term rental listings dropped precipitously between May 2020 and March 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: India bars Mastercard from adding new customers over a data violation.
description: The Reserve Bank of India said financial services company had not complied with a 2018 order to store data on local transactions only in the country.
content: NEW DELHI — India on Wednesday barred Mastercard from adding new customers in the country over claims that it had violated the country’s data storage laws, a blow to the company in a market it was investing in heavily for expansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: On Voting Rights, Justice Alito Is Stuck in the 1980s
description: A clash among justices over what constitutes the right to vote mirrors the partisan divide on the question.
content: The Voting Rights Act decision that concluded the Supreme Court term this month offered two mutually exclusive visions of what the right to vote means today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Where a Zipper Gets Caught
description: Max Carpenter grumbles his way through his debut.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — One of the best parts of solving puzzles every day for a living — other than the fact that I get to solve puzzles every day for a living — is watching how constructors can take an idea, put their own spin on it and make an entirely unique crossword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: The Developing World Is a Tinderbox
description: Without vaccines, desperate countries are running out of hope.
content: The images flooding out of riot-torn South Africa are horrifying. On Tuesday, a woman in a high-rise building apparently set alight by looters tossed her child to the hoped-for safety of a crowd far below. Emergency workers have been attacked in several places; one medical service began transporting the injured in an armored ambulance. In much of the central district of the port city of Durban, the police were overwhelmed and shopping malls and stores were gutted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Dodd
title: The West’s fourth major heat wave will roast the northern Rockies.
description: Potentially record-setting temperatures are coming to parts of Montana, Idaho, Wyoming and Utah.
content: Another weekend is set to bring another string of potentially record-breaking high temperatures to another part of the Western United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Myanmar’s junta hoards oxygen as cases climb.
content: The military has ordered that the lifesaving gas be withheld from private clinics and has even stopped charities from giving it away, medical workers say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Wedding Traditions
description: The judge weighs in on a fiancé’s cake-smash compromise.
content: Brandon writes: My fiancée, Ashley, is against wedding traditions like the garter toss and particularly the “cake smash,” where bride and groom smear frosting on each other’s face. But I’m a big fan of these traditions! Please order a cake-smash compromise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Records of Arizona’s review of the 2020 election must be made public, a judge rules.
description: Republican state senators overseeing a review of the 2020 election in Arizona’s most populous county must make public the records of private companies hired to conduct the audit, a county judge ruled on Thursday, emphatically rejecting a bid by the senators to keep the documents secret.
content: Republican state senators overseeing a review of the 2020 election in Arizona’s most populous county must make public the records of private companies hired to conduct the audit, a county judge ruled on Thursday, emphatically rejecting a bid by the senators to keep the documents secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Review: ‘Schmigadoon!’ Has a Song in Its Heart, and Everywhere Else
description: The Apple TV+ series both mocks and embraces the glories of classic musicals like “Brigadoon,” “Oklahoma!” and “Carousel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: A blame game intensifies over Australia’s sluggish immunization campaign.
description: Only about 9.5 percent of the population has been fully inoculated. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said that “cautious” guidance from the country’s vaccine advisory body had “put us behind.”
content: Politicians and medical experts in Australia are trading blame for a slow vaccine rollout as the country struggles to contain a coronavirus outbreak in Sydney, its biggest city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian Matejka and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: Bullet (Lead + Alloy)
description: Adrian Matejka does here what all good poets do, startles you with a reminder, even a simple one.
content: When my son asks, Did you have a gun, after listening to me tell strangers of my crimes and time in prison, I want to lie. Unable to reconcile those yesterdays with what I know now about bullets. Maybe what I knew then. Adrian Matejka does here what all good poets do, startles you with a reminder, even a simple one: “Here we are/again: so many Black women/& Black men in front of it.” The it being a gun, whether wielded by the police, or as is more often the case, another Black hand. As Grandmaster Flash once said, It’s like a jungle sometimes it makes me wonder how I keep from going under. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: 17 New York Arts Organizations Are Among Those Receiving $30 Million
description: The Queens Museum, Harlem Stage and 44 other groups were chosen to receive aid from Bloomberg Philanthropies for digital innovation.
content: The Queens Museum is among 46 cultural nonprofit organizations selected for a new $30 million program by Bloomberg Philanthropies that is intended to support improving technology at the groups and helping them stabilize and thrive in the wake of the pandemic. A Bloomberg Tech Fellow is being appointed at each organization, the philanthropies announced Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx
description: This week’s properties are in the Williamsburg, the East Village and Fieldston.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Tackles Books About Trump’s Time in Office
description: Tell-alls about the Trump presidency include “Landslide,” “Betrayal” and “Nightmare Scenario,” “which is also how the former president describes having to read a book,” Colbert joked on Wednesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Jim Tankersley
title: As the first child tax credit payments go out, Biden hails it as a step toward ending child poverty.
description: For now, the monthly payments apply to 2021 only, although President Biden and some members of Congress hope to extend it for years.
content: President Biden appeared on Thursday to deliver a speech marking the day that millions of Americans will begin receiving hundreds of dollars per month through a child tax credit established as part of the coronavirus relief package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ed Shanahan
title: He Paid His Subway Fare. Then He Was Tasered by the Police.
description: A video of a violent arrest raised questions about balancing a push to enforce laws in the subway against concerns about police abuses.
content: A video of police officers swarming a subway rider and shooting him with a Taser this month has revived a contentious debate about policing on New York’s public transit system, even as the person likely to lead the city has made subway safety a top priority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Johnson & Johnson Recalls Sunscreen Because of Benzene Traces
description: The company said it had determined that daily exposure to five Neutrogena and Aveeno sprays would not cause adverse health effects, but recalled the products out of an abundance of caution.
content: Johnson & Johnson issued a voluntary recall on Wednesday for five of its sunscreen sprays after testing found low levels of benzene, a carcinogen, in the products. Consumers were told to stop using the products and throw them out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: In England, a Call to Tax Sugar and Salt
description: The tax on salt and sugar in processed and restaurant-made foods was among several measures proposed in a sweeping review into England’s food industry.
content: LONDON — With England trapped in what it calls a vicious circle of junk food consumption, the authors of a government-commissioned review into the nation’s food industry have put sugar and salt in their cross hairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Gunman Is Found Criminally Responsible for Killing 5 at Capital Gazette
description: The finding means that Jarrod W. Ramos will be sentenced to spend the rest of his life in prison for one of the deadliest attacks on American journalists.
content: More than three years after a man carrying a deep-seated grudge and a shotgun blasted his way into a newsroom in Annapolis, Md., and killed five employees, a jury found Thursday that he was sane at the time and criminally responsible for his actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: As Covid Rages in Myanmar, Army Hoards Oxygen, Doctors Say
description: The military has ordered oxygen withheld from private clinics and even stopped charities from giving it away, medical workers and others say.
content: First, the junta stole Myanmar’s elected leaders from the people. Now, doctors say, the generals have taken the oxygen that some citizens need to breathe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
title: Wearing a Head Scarf Can Be Grounds for Job Suspension, E.U.’s Top Court Rules
description: The court upheld a decision that companies can ban head scarves or other religious symbols in the workplace in the interest of “a neutral image.”
content: The European Union’s highest court reaffirmed on Thursday that companies in Europe can bar women from wearing head scarves on the job, a ruling that holds consequences for the balance between the freedom of religion and the rights of employers to apply policies requiring religious neutrality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: It’s a Jeep Thing, but by Now, You Probably Understand
description: After 80 years, the King of the Off-Road is vying to maintain its cult following while it charts its electric future.
content: Born for the battlefield, the first Jeeps rolled off assembly lines in 1941 and headed straight to active duty for the United States Army. They would “forever be known for helping win a world war,” according to a history of the brand, which had bold plans early on, according to one imperial slogan: “The Sun Never Sets on the Mighty Jeep.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The Hidden Life of Trees’ Review: Magic Kingdom
description: Jörg Adolph uses the sensorial capacities of cinema to thrillingly visualize a German forester’s contention that trees are social, sentient beings.
content: In his best-selling book, “The Hidden Life of Trees,” the German forester Peter Wohlleben drew in millions of readers with a tantalizing hypothesis: that trees are social, sentient beings, who talk to each other, feed and nurse their young, sense pain and have personalities. While Wohlleben’s anthropomorphic language and seductive blend of science and speculation rankled some professionals, this was precisely the selling point for lay readers: an opportunity to see how trees share some of our own traits, and are worthy of our empathy and care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Infrastructure, Haiti, San Francisco: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and William K. Rashbaum
title: Cuomo to Be Questioned in Sexual Harassment Inquiry
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is expected to face investigators on Saturday in a sign that the attorney general’s inquiry may be nearing its final stages.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to be questioned on Saturday by investigators from the New York State attorney general’s office, signaling that a four-month-long inquiry into several sexual harassment accusations may be entering its final stages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Hundreds Missing and Scores Dead as Raging Floods Strike Western Europe
description: Strong rains caused rivers to burst their banks and wash away buildings in Belgium and Germany, where at least 1,300 remained missing. Homes and streets in the Netherlands and Switzerland also flooded.
content: BERLIN — Following a day of frantic rescue efforts and orders to evacuate towns rapidly filling with water unloosed by violent storms, the German authorities said late Thursday that after confirming scores of deaths, they were unable to account for at least 1,300 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: N.C.A.A. Chief, Under Pressure, Says College Sports May Need Reorganization
description: “We need to reconsider delegation of a lot of the things that are now done at the national level,” Mark Emmert told reporters on Thursday.
content: The president of the N.C.A.A., whose organization was undercut last month by a Supreme Court ruling, said Thursday that the college sports industry should weigh transferring more authority to leagues and schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Acknowledging Disagreements, Biden and Merkel Signal Warmer U.S.-German Ties
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s trip appeared to be a triumph of the personal over policy. The two leaders exchanged friendly banter, but there were no apparent breakthroughs on a Russian pipeline or how to approach China.
content: WASHINGTON — Signaling that the U.S.-European alliance remained strong after the tension of the Trump era, President Biden and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday stressed their shared values, even as both acknowledged differences on a major Russian pipeline and how best to approach China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Raise Kids Who Won’t Be Racist
description: Research shows that talking openly about race makes children more empathetic and raises their self-esteem.
content: If race is largely a social construct, then teaching children about it will only perpetuate racism — right? Wrong: Studies show precisely the opposite. Open conversations about race and racism can make white children less prejudiced and can increase the self-esteem of children of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Regrets in South Africa After Lives and Livelihoods Lost in Mass Unrest
description: The manager of a looted supermarket in Soweto and a man who joined in ransacking it reflect on the causes and consequences of some of the worst unrest to hit parts of South Africa since the fall of apartheid.
content: SOWETO, South Africa — Gingerly stepping over the slick, muddied floor of a supermarket in Soweto that had just been emptied and gutted by looters, the manager fretted over where neighbors would now get their food and how he would support his wife and four children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Boston Overhauls Admissions to Exclusive Exam Schools
description: A new policy will increase representation of Black and Latino students in the prestigious public schools, which serve as a gateway to elite colleges.
content: BOSTON — Long into the night on Wednesday, parents and students waited in line to say their piece about Boston Latin School and who deserves to attend it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘The Works and Days’ Review: The Time of Our Lives
description: This eight-hour drama follows a woman’s life on her family’s farm.
content: In “The Works and Days (of Tayoko Shiojiri in the Shiotani Basin),” a woman moves through life on her family’s farm in a Japanese mountain village. As her husband falls ill, she spends more and more time on the chores, though visits from friends and relatives bring comfort and joy. Shot over 14 months, the film is a life event in and of itself, spanning eight hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Mark Warner, a ‘Business Guy’ Democrat, Lands Back in the Fray
description: Virginia’s senior senator spent years in the Capitol eyeing the exits. Now he is seen as a “linchpin” in talks on infrastructure, social and environmental spending, and the tax increases to pay for it.
content: WASHINGTON — In his days as Virginia’s governor, Mark Warner had a reputation for playing rough under the boards with young Republican lawmakers on the basketball court. But he would follow his flying elbows with a pat on the back, a wry smile and often an invitation to the governor’s mansion for Grey Goose vodka shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Two Accounts of Donald Trump’s Final Year in Office, One More Vivid and Apt Than the Other
description: “I Alone Can Fix It,” by Carol Leonnig and Philip Rucker, and “Landslide,” by Michael Wolff, take different approaches to recounting the events of 2020 and early 2021.
content: Two new books about the final year of Donald J. Trump’s presidency are entering the cultural bloodstream. The first, “Landslide,” by the gadfly journalist Michael Wolff, is the one to leap upon, even though the second, “I Alone Can Fix It,” from the Washington Post journalists Carol Leonnig and Philip Rucker, is vastly more earnest and diligent, to a fault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Tech Workers Who Swore Off the Bay Area Are Coming Back
description: Critics said the pandemic would make the industry flee San Francisco and its southern neighbor, Silicon Valley. But tech can’t seem to quit its gravitational center.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Last year, Greg Osuri decided he’d had enough of the Bay Area. Between smoke-choked air from nearby wildfires and the coronavirus lockdown, it felt as if the walls of his apartment in San Francisco’s Twin Peaks neighborhood were closing in on him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are in Thornwood, N.Y., and Westport, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: On the Children’s Series Best-Seller List, the Name of the Game Is Fantasy
description: Readers of all ages are looking for otherworldly escape — and lots of it.
content: SERIAL PILLAR For readers of a certain age, there are few experiences more rewarding than watching a young bookworm get wrapped up in an engrossing story. Sometimes we catch a glimpse of this kindred mania via the glow of a flashlight under covers — which, unfortunately, may turn out to be a phone streaming TikTok. But most often we bear witness while face to face with a kid who has just finished one book in a series and is asking, with a desperate gleam in his eye, “Can I get the next one? Please?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Covid Surge Shuts Down West End Shows
description: Many London theaters are canceling performances, and people in the industry fear that more productions will have to close when England ends distancing and mask-wearing requirements next week.
content: LONDON — The cast and crew of “Seven Methods of Killing Kylie Jenner,” an experimental play at the Royal Court, were just two weeks into their run when they received some bad news: One member of the company had tested positive for the coronavirus, and everyone had to quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Los Angeles Criticized After Release of 17 Million Gallons of Sewage Closes Beaches
description: Officials took more than 12 hours to alert the public about the discharge, drawing a rebuke from environmental watchdogs and elected representatives.
content: Seventeen million gallons of raw sewage were discharged into Santa Monica Bay earlier this week after a sprawling wastewater treatment plant in Los Angeles experienced problems, prompting several beach closures more than 12 hours later that were sharply criticized for not happening sooner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Work Injuries Tied to Heat Are Vastly Undercounted, Study Finds
description: New data underline how heat waves can hurt people, especially the poorest workers, in unexpected ways.
content: Extreme heat causes many times more workplace injuries than official records capture, and those injuries are concentrated among the poorest workers, new research suggests, the latest evidence of how climate change worsens inequality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Yankees’ Shutdown Emphasizes Staying Power of the Coronavirus
description: The team has three confirmed breakthrough cases, and may add three more positive cases in an outbreak that could affect multiple All-Stars.
content: At 4:45 p.m. on Thursday afternoon, Alex Rodriguez stood up in the ESPN broadcast booth at Yankee Stadium and motioned down to the sun-splashed field, arms outstretched and palms turned up — the universal look of confusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Esther Bejarano, 96, Dies; Auschwitz Survivor Fought Hate With Hip-Hop
description: She played the accordion in the camp’s orchestra. Decades later, she spoke out against fascism and racism, using music as well as words.
content: When Esther Bejarano was 18, she played accordion in the women’s orchestra at Auschwitz, which played marches as prisoners left the concentration camp for hard labor and upbeat music as train loads of Jews and others arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Steve Knopper
title: Dispute Over James Brown Estate Largely Ends as Heirs Agree on Plan
description: After nearly 15 years, the settlement may allow administrators to fund a trust outlined in the musician’s will that would finance the education of underprivileged children.
content: For nearly 15 years, James Brown’s estate has been one of the most contentious legal cases in the entertainment industry, involving volleys of lawsuits among his children, his former romantic partner and its various administrators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Jeremy O. Harris Takes His Twitter Friends to the Movies
description: “Almost everyone I’ve met tells me it is their first time in a theater post-pandemic,” Mr. Harris said. “I want to do it in community.”
content: On a recent overcast Tuesday afternoon, a small crowd formed outside of the Village East by Angelika on 12th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan. The gaggle of strangers had been invited on Twitter by Jeremy O. Harris, the “Slave Play” playwright and man about town, to watch the film “Zola.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: After a Steep Plunge in Virus Cases, Every State Is Seeing an Uptick
description: Hospitals are stretched thin in a few hot spots, but the vaccines are working and the national outlook remains far better than during previous surges.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The number of new coronavirus cases is increasing in every state, setting off a growing sense of concern from health officials who are warning that the pandemic in the United States is far from over, even though the national outlook is far better than during previous upticks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Summer Movies That Deliver Chills and Skyline Views
description: Outdoor venues in and around the city are reliable resources for scary movies this summer. Here are our picks, for the squeamish and slasher-lover alike.
content: The outdoors is a terrible place to be if you’re in a horror movie being pursued by a knife-wielding maniac. He’ll always know the woods better than you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: A Wine Worth Waiting For
description: The 2005 Bordeaux vintage will require decades to evolve and develop. Is that better than wines that are terrific sooner, but not as majestic?
content: It’s only 2021, and we’ve already had possibly seven red Bordeaux vintages of the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Iraqi Authorities Revise Down Death Toll in Covid Hospital Fire
description: Regional health officials now say 60 died, not 92 as initially reported by the state news media.
content: NASIRIYA, Iraq — Regional officials on Thursday revised down the death toll from a fire that swept through a hospital’s coronavirus ward in southern Iraq this week, saying they had confirmed 60 victims instead of the 92 initially reported by the state news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Frustrated with lagging military vaccinations, an Alabama base requires some G.I.s to provide proof of shots.
description: Fort Rucker, with 5,000 uniformed soldiers, is in a state where the Delta variant is driving up coronavirus cases and hospitalizations.
content: About 68 percent of members of the U.S. military have had at least one dose of a Covid vaccine, but given that only full vaccination affords significant protection against the more infectious Delta variant surging in parts of the United States, American commanders are seeking new ways to pressure, entice and cajole service members to get their shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: California’s heat wave could wipe out all of the young salmon in the Sacramento River.
description: Officials said that the drought is also contributing to to the crisis.
content: Abnormally warm water from the punishing heat that has settled on much of the West this summer and a lack of water during the worst drought in decades are threatening the endangered Chinook salmon population in the Sacramento River, officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Parker
title: Texas Should Be a Warning to Democrats Everywhere
description: America should pay attention to what has gone awfully wrong in the Lone Star State.
content: Pretty soon, Texans will openly carry loaded firearms into grocery stores, gas stations and even airports. Women will effectively be unable to get a legal abortion. And schoolchildren won’t learn, at least not legally, the unvarnished story about discrimination or racism. And a bunch of Texas legislators are hanging around Washington, D.C., trying to derail draconian restrictions on voting rights in their home state.­
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: Haiti receives its first shipment of vaccines: 500,000 doses from the U.S.
description: The donation comes amid political turmoil after the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.
content: A shipment of 500,000 Covid vaccine doses from the United States arrived in Haiti on Wednesday, the first shots to reach a nation thrown into turmoil after the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Frances Robles and Julie Turkewitz
title: Suspects in Haitian President’s Killing Met to Plan a Future Without Him
description: Haitian officials accuse the suspects of meeting to plot President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination, but participants say the sessions were intended to plan a government once the president stepped down.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Several of the central figures under investigation by the Haitian authorities in connection with the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse gathered in the months before the killing to discuss rebuilding the troubled nation once the president was out of power, according to the Haitian police, Colombian intelligence officers and participants in the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: Last summer, when just about the only dance performances on offer were those on film, the annual Dance on Camera festival provided an angle of expertise: works that were on film by design rather than by necessity. Because the festival was virtual, though, it had to forgo one of its usual aims: projecting its picks on a big screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: It Seems Odd That We Would Just Let the World Burn
description: Where is the urgency on climate change?
content: I spent the weekend reading a book I wasn’t entirely comfortable being seen with in public. Andreas Malm’s “How to Blow Up a Pipeline” is only slightly inaptly named. You won’t find, anywhere inside, instructions on sabotaging energy infrastructure. A truer title would be “Why to Blow Up a Pipeline.” On this, Malm’s case is straightforward: Because nothing else has worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Pig’ Review: Come Back, Trotter
description: Nicolas Cage plays a reclusive truffle hunter in this fiercely controlled character drama.
content: Shielded by a rat’s-nest beard and layers of decaying clothing, Rob (Nicolas Cage) lives in a rudimentary cabin in the Oregon wilderness with his beloved pig. Together, they forage for truffles that Rob barters for necessities when Amir (an indispensable Alex Wolff) makes his weekly visit. The truffles are bound for high-end Portland restaurants; when the pig is stolen, her owner will be compelled to follow the fungi.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Reporting About Food Led to a Story About Slavery
description: After the correspondent Kim Severson came across the disturbing roots of a family farm, the pandemic provided what she needed most to find out more: time.
content: Early on in my career as a national correspondent, an editor told me to always leave room for a story to jump in front of you. Stacie Marshall, who inherited 300 acres of farmland in north Georgia and discovered her ancestors had enslaved seven people, was one of those stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The American Identity Crisis
description: America is withdrawing just as the world’s reactionaries make their push.
content: For most of the past century, human dignity had a friend — the United States of America. We are a deeply flawed and error-prone nation, like any other, but America helped defeat fascism and communism and helped set the context for European peace, Asian prosperity and the spread of democracy.

author: By David Gelles
title: Hubert Joly Turned Around Best Buy. Now He’s Trying to Fix Capitalism.
description: “The more taxes I pay, the happier I am,” says Mr. Joly, who is waging a campaign to get big business to be more socially responsible.
content: When Hubert Joly took over Best Buy in 2012, the electronics retailer was struggling to compete with Amazon, discount retailers like Walmart and a broad shift away from brick-and-mortar shopping. Sales and profits were sagging, and the stock price had cratered.

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Can You Bring It: Bill T. Jones and D-Man in the Waters’ Review: Still Making Waves
description: A striking new documentary explores the enduring legacy of a dance piece created by Bill T. Jones at the height of the AIDS crisis.
content: What happens to a work of art when time displaces it from its original context, and from the impetus that inspired it? That’s a question that can elicit dry theories. But in “Can You Bring It?: Bill T. Jones and D-Man in the Waters,” a new documentary directed by Tom Hurwitz and Rosalynde LeBlanc Loo, the answer is passionate and moving.

Trump to introduce logging and mining in pristine sections of one of the world’s largest intact temperate rain forests.

description: An H.I.V. infection increases the odds of dying from Covid-19 by at least 30 percent, researchers said.
content: People living with H.I.V. are more likely to become severely ill with Covid-19 and more likely to die if hospitalized than others infected with the coronavirus, according to a large new study.
